{{for|the album by Sole & DJ Pain 1|Death Drive (album)}} {{missing|the modern scientific perspective|date=September 2016}} {{psychoanalysis}} In classical [[Freudian]] [[psychoanalytic theory]], the '''death drive''' ({{lang-de|Todestrieb}}) is the [[Drive theory|drive]] toward death and self-destruction. It was originally proposed by [[Sabina Spielrein]] in her paper "Destruction as the Cause of Coming Into Being"<ref>{{cite journal |last=Spielrein |first=Sabina |date=April 1994 |title=Destruction as the Cause of Coming Into Being |journal=Journal of Analytical Psychology |volume=39 |issue=2 |pages=155–186 |doi=10.1111/j.1465-5922.1994.00155.x}} [http://www.arizonapsychoanalyticsociety.com/downloads/sabrina.pdf Free pdf of the full essay] by the Arizona Psychoanalytic Society.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Spielrein |first=Sabina |year=1995 |title=Destruction as Cause of Becoming |journal=Psychoanalysis and Contemporary Thought |volume=18 |issue= |pages=85–118|doi= |url=http://www.pep-web.org/document.php?id=pct.018.0085a}}</ref> (''Die Destruktion als Ursache des Werdens'')<ref>{{de icon}} {{cite journal |last=Spielrein |first=Sabina |year=1912 |title=''Die Destruktion als Ursache des Werdens'' |journal=Jahrbuch für Psychoanalytische und Psychopathologische Forschungen |volume=IV |issue= |pages=465–503 |doi= |url=https://archive.org/stream/JahrbuchFuumlrPsychoanalytischeUndPsychopathologischeForschungenIv_509/JdP_IV_1912_1_Haelfte#page/n467/mode/2up}}</ref> in 1912, which was then taken up by [[Sigmund Freud]] in 1920 in ''[[Beyond the Pleasure Principle]].'' This concept has been translated as "opposition between the ego or death [[instinct]]s and the sexual or life instincts".<ref>Sigmund Freud, "Beyond the Pleasure Principle" in ''On Metapsychology'' (Middlesex 1987), p. 316.</ref> In ''Pleasure Principle'', Freud used the plural "death drives" (''Todestriebe'') much more frequently than in the singular.<ref>See occurrences of [https://books.google.com/?id=LQcUz3FVkNQC&q=%22death+drives%22 "death drives"] and of [https://books.google.com/?id=LQcUz3FVkNQC&q=%22death+drive%22 "death drive"].</ref>
The death drive opposes [[Eros (concept)#Sigmund Freud|Eros]], the tendency toward survival, propagation, sex, and other creative, life-producing drives. The death drive is sometimes referred to as "[[Thanatos]]" in post-Freudian thought, complementing "Eros", although this term was not used in Freud's own work, being rather introduced by [[Wilhelm Stekel]] in 1909 and then by [[Paul Federn]] in the present context.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jones |first=Ernest |authorlink=Ernest Jones |title=The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud. Volume 3 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=0nwIAQAAIAAJ |year=1957 |origyear=[https://books.google.com/?id=_NBLAQAAMAAJ 1953] |publisher=[[Basic Books]] |location=New York City |page=273 |quote=[https://books.google.com/?id=0nwIAQAAIAAJ&q=%22It+is+a+little+odd+that+Freud+himself+never,+except+in+conversation,+used+for+the+death+instinct+the+term+Thanatos,+one+which+has+become+so+popular+since%22 It is a little odd that Freud himself never, except in conversation, used for the death instinct the term ''Thanatos'', one which has become so popular since.] [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Stekel+had+in+1909+used+the+word+Thanatos+to+signify+a+death-wish%2C22+but+it+was+Federn+who+introduced+it+in+the+present+context%22 At first he used the terms "death instinct" and "destructive instinct" indiscriminately, alternating between them, but in his discussion with Einstein about war he made the distinction that the former is directed against the self and the latter, derived from it, is directed outward. Stekel had in 1909 used the word Thanatos to signify a death-wish, but it was Federn who introduced it in the present context.]}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first1=Jean |last1=Laplanche |first2=Jean-Bertrand |last2=Pontalis |authorlink1=Jean Laplanche |authorlink2=Jean-Bertrand Pontalis |chapter=Thanatos (p. 447) |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/?id=DCpokE8C2WgC&pg=PA447&dq=%22D.:+Thanatos%22%22Greek+term+%28%3D+Death%29%22#v=onepage&q=%22D.:+Thanatos%22%22Greek+term+(=+Death)%22|title=The Language of Psycho-analysis |url=https://books.google.com/?id=DCpokE8C2WgC&printsec=frontcover |publisher=Karnac Books| location=London |year=1988 |edition=reprint, revised |origyear=[https://books.google.com/?id=tV99AAAAMAAJ 1973] |isbn=978-0-946-43949-2}}</ref>
The Standard Edition of Freud's works in English confuses two terms that are different in German, ''Instinkt'' ("instinct") and ''Trieb'' ("drive"), often translating both as ''instinct''; for example, "the hypothesis of a ''death instinct'', the task of which is to lead organic life back into the inanimate state".<ref>Sigmund Freud, "The Ego and the Id", in ''On Metapsychology'' (Middlesex, 1987), p. 380.</ref> "This equating of ''instinkt'' and ''Trieb'' has created serious misunderstandings".<ref>Otto Fenichel, ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'', (London, 1946), p. 12.</ref><ref>Laplanche, Jean; Pontalis, Jean-Bertrand (1988) [1973]. "[https://books.google.com/?id=DCpokE8C2WgC&pg=PA214&dq=%22Instinct+(or+Drive)+=+I.+D.:+Instinkt%22%22D.:+Trieb%22 Instinct (or Drive) (pp. 214-7).]"</ref> Freud actually refers to the term "instinkt" in explicit use elsewhere,<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Nagera |editor-first=Humberto |chapter=Instinct and Drive (pp. 19ff.) |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/?id=qbWuAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA19&dq=%22Instinct+and+Drive%22 |title=Basic Psychoanalytic Concepts on the Theory of Instincts |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qbWuAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |year=2014 |origyear=[https://books.google.com/?id=qnowAAAAIAAJ 1970] |publisher=[[Routledge]] |location=[[Abingdon-on-Thames]] |isbn=978-1-317-67045-2 |id={{ISBN|1-31767045-0}}}}</ref> and so while the concept of "instinct" can loosely be referred to as a "drive," any essentialist or naturalist connotations of the term should be put in abeyance. In a sense, the death drive is a force that is not essential to the life of an organism (unlike an "instinct") and tends to denature it or make it behave in ways that are sometimes counter-intuitive. In other words, the term death "drive" is simply a false representation of death instinct. The term is almost universally known in scholarly literature on Freud as the "death drive", and Lacanian psychoanalysts often shorten it to simply "drive" (although Freud posited the existence of other drives as well, and [[Jacques Lacan|Lacan]] explicitly states in Seminar XI that all drives are partial to the death drive).<ref>{{Cite book|title=The four fundamental concepts of psychoanalysis|last=|first=|publisher=W.W. Norton|year=|isbn=9780393317756|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> The contemporary Penguin translations of Freud translate ''Trieb'' and ''Instinkt'' as "drive" and "instinct" respectively.
==Origin of the theory: ''Beyond the Pleasure Principle''== {{Main|Beyond the Pleasure Principle}} {{Anchors|origin}}It was a basic premise of Freud's that "the course taken by mental events is automatically regulated by the pleasure principle...[associated] with an avoidance of unpleasure or a production of pleasure".<ref>Freud, "Beyond the Pleasure Principle", p. 275.</ref> Three main types of conflictual evidence, difficult to explain satisfactorily in such terms, led Freud late in his career to look for another principle in mental life ''beyond'' the [[pleasure principle (psychology)|pleasure principle]]—a search that would ultimately lead him to the concept of the death drive.
The first problem Freud encountered was the phenomenon of repetition in (war) trauma. When Freud worked with people with [[Psychological trauma|trauma]] (particularly the trauma experienced by soldiers returning from [[World War I]]), he observed that subjects often tended to repeat or re-enact these traumatic experiences: "dreams occurring in traumatic have the characteristic of repeatedly bringing the patient back into the situation of his accident",<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 282.</ref> contrary to the expectations of the pleasure principle.
A second problematic area was found by Freud in children's [[Play (activity)|play]] (such as the ''Fort/Da'' [Forth/here] game played by Freud's grandson, who would stage and re-stage the disappearance of his mother and even himself). "How then does his repetition of this distressing experience as a game fit in with the pleasure principle?"<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 285.</ref>
The third problem came from clinical practice. Freud found his patients, dealing with painful experiences that had been repressed, regularly "obliged to ''repeat'' the repressed material as a contemporary experience instead of [...] ''remembering'' it as something belonging to the past".<ref>Freud, "Beyond" p. 288.</ref> Combined with what he called "the compulsion of destiny [...] come across [in] people all of whose human relationships have the same outcome",<ref>Freud, "Beyond" p. 294 and p. 292.</ref> such evidence led Freud "to justify the hypothesis of a compulsion to repeat—something that would seem more primitive, more elementary, more instinctual than the pleasure principle which it over-rides".<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 294.</ref>
He then set out to find an explanation of such a compulsion; in Freud's own words, "What follows is speculation, often far-fetched speculation, which the reader will consider or dismiss according to his individual predilection".<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 295.</ref> Seeking a new instinctual paradigm for such problematic repetition, he found it ultimately in "''an urge in organic life to restore an earlier state of things''"<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 308.</ref>—the inorganic state from which life originally emerged. From the conservative, restorative character of instinctual life, Freud derived his death drive, with its "pressure towards death", and the resulting "separation of the death instincts from the life instincts"<ref>Freud, "Beyond", pp. 316 and 322.</ref> seen in Eros. The death drive then manifested itself in the individual creature as a force "whose function is to assure that the organism shall follow its own path to death".<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 311.</ref>
Seeking further potential clinical support for the existence of such a self-destructive force, Freud found it through a reconsideration of his views of masochism—previously "regarded as sadism that has been turned round upon the subject's own ego"—so as to allow that "there ''might'' be such a thing as primary masochism—a possibility which I had contested"<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 328.</ref> before. Even with such support, however, he remained very tentative to the book's close about the provisional nature of his theoretical construct: what he called "the whole of our artificial structure of hypotheses".<ref>Freud, "Beyond", p. 334.</ref>
Although Spielrein's paper was published in 1912, Freud initially resisted the concept as he considered it to be too Jungian. Nevertheless, Freud eventually adopted the concept, and in later years would build extensively upon the tentative foundations he had set out in ''Beyond the Pleasure Principle''. In ''[[The Ego and the Id]]'' (1923) he would develop his argument to state that "the death instinct would thus seem to express itself—though probably only in part—as an ''instinct of destruction'' directed against the external world".<ref>Freud, "Ego/Id", p. 381.</ref> The following year he would spell out more clearly that the "libido has the task of making the destroying instinct innocuous, and it fulfils the task by diverting that instinct to a great extent outwards [...]. The instinct is then called the destructive instinct, the instinct for mastery, or the will to power",<ref>Freud, "The Economic Problem of Masochism" in ''On Metapsychology'', p. 418.</ref> a perhaps much more recognisable set of manifestations.
At the close of the decade, in ''[[Civilization and Its Discontents]]'' (1930), Freud acknowledged that "To begin with it was only tentatively that I put forward the views I have developed here, but in the course of time they have gained such a hold upon me that I can no longer think in any other way".<ref>Sigmund Freud, "Civilization and Its Discontents", in ''Civilization, Society and Religion'' (Middlesex, 1987), p. 311.</ref>
==Philosophy== {{see also|Arthur Schopenhauer#Philosophy of the "Will"{{!}}Philosophy of the "Will" in Schopenhauer}} From a philosophical perspective, the death drive may be viewed in relation to the work of the German philosopher [[Arthur Schopenhauer]]. His philosophy, expounded in ''[[The World as Will and Representation]]'' (1818) postulates that all exists by a metaphysical "will" (more clearly, a '''will to live'''<ref>{{Cite book|last= Schopenhauer |first=Arthur |title=The World as Will and Presentation |others=Translated by Richard E. Aquila and David Carus |location= New York |publisher= Longman |year= 2008}}</ref>), and that pleasure affirms this will. Schopenhauer's [[pessimism]] led him to believe that the affirmation of the "will" was a negative and immoral thing, due to his belief of life producing more suffering than happiness. The death drive would seem to manifest as a natural and psychological negation of the "will".
Freud was well aware of such possible linkages. In a letter of 1919, he wrote that regarding "the theme of death, [that I] have stumbled onto an odd idea via the drives and must now read all sorts of things that belong to it, for instance Schopenhauer".<ref>Quoted in Peter Gay, ''Freud: A life for our time'' (London, 1989), p. 391.</ref> Indeed, [[Ernest Jones]] (who like many analysts was not convinced of the need for the death drive, over and above an instinct of aggression) considered that "Freud seemed to have landed in the position of Schopenhauer, who taught that 'death is the goal of life'".<ref>Ernest Jones, ''The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud'' (London, 1964), p. 508.</ref>
However, as Freud put it to the imagined auditors of his ''New Introductory Lectures'' (1932), "You may perhaps shrug your shoulders and say: "That isn't natural science, it's Schopenhauer's philosophy!" But, ladies and gentlemen, why should not a bold thinker have guessed something that is afterwards confirmed by sober and painstaking detailed research?"<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''New Introductory Lectures on Psychoanalysis'' (London, 1991), pp. 140-1.</ref> He then went on to add that "what we are saying is not even genuine Schopenhauer....we are not overlooking the fact that there is life as well as death. We recognise two basic instincts and give each of them its own aim".<ref>Freud, ''New'', p. 141.</ref>
==Cultural application: ''Civilization and Its Discontents''== {{Main|Civilization and Its Discontents}} Freud applied his new theoretical construct in ''Civilization and Its Discontents'' (1930) to the difficulties inherent in [[western culture|Western civilization]]—indeed, in civilization and in social life as a whole. In particular, given that "a portion of the [death] instinct is diverted towards the external world and comes to light as an instinct of aggressiveness', he saw 'the inclination to aggression [...] [as] the greatest impediment to civilization".<ref>Freud, ''Civilization'' pp. 310 and 313.</ref> The need to overcome such aggression entailed the formation of the [cultural] superego: "We have even been guilty of the heresy of attributing the origin of conscience to this diversion inwards of aggressiveness".<ref>Freud, "Why War?" in ''Civilization'', p. 358.</ref> The presence thereafter in the individual of the superego and a related sense of guilt—"Civilization, therefore, obtains mastery over the individual's dangerous desire for aggression by [...] setting up an agency within him to watch over it"<ref>Freud, ''Civilization'', p. 316.</ref>—leaves an abiding sense of uneasiness inherent in civilized life, thereby providing a structural explanation for 'the suffering of civilized man'.<ref>Jacques Lacan, ''Ecrits: A Selection'' (London, 1997), p. 69.</ref>
Freud made a further connection between [[Group (sociology)|group]] life and innate aggression, where the former comes together more closely by directing aggression to other groups, an idea later picked up by group analysts like [[Wilfred Bion]].
==Continuing development of Freud's views== In the closing decade of Freud's life, it has been suggested, his view of the death drive changed somewhat, with "the stress much more upon the death instinct's manifestations ''outwards''".<ref>Albert Dickson, "Editor's Introduction", ''Civilization'', p. 249.</ref> Given "the ubiquity of non-erotic aggressivity and destructiveness", he wrote in 1930, "I adopt the standpoint, therefore, that the inclination to aggression is an original, self-subsisting instinctual disposition in man".<ref>Freud, ''Civilization'', pp. 311 and 313.</ref>
In 1933 he conceded of his original formulation of the death drive 'the improbability of our speculations. A queer instinct, indeed, directed to the destruction of its own organic home!'.<ref>Freud, ''New'', p. 139.</ref> He wrote moreover that "Our hypothesis is that there are two essentially different classes of instincts: the sexual instincts, understood in the widest sense—Eros, if you prefer that name—and the aggressive instincts, whose aim is destruction".<ref>Freud, ''New'', p. 136.</ref> In 1937, he went so far as to suggest privately that 'We should have a neat schematic picture if we supposed that originally, at the beginning of life, all libido was directed to the inside and all aggressiveness to the outside'.<ref>Freud quoted by Dickson, ''Civilization'', p. 249.</ref> In his last writings, it was the contrast of "two basic instincts, ''Eros'' and ''the destructive instinct'' [...] our two primal instincts, ''Eros'' and ''destructiveness'',<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''Standard Edition'' vol. xxiii (London 1964), pp. 148 and 246.</ref> on which he laid stress. Nevertheless, his belief in "the death instinct [...] [as] a return to an earlier state [...] into an inorganic state"<ref>Freud, ''SE'', xxiii, pp. 148-9.</ref> continued to the end.
==Analytic reception== As Freud wryly commented in 1930, "The assumption of the existence of an instinct of death or destruction has met with resistance even in analytic circles".<ref>Freud, ''Civilization'', p. 310.</ref> Indeed, Ernest Jones would comment of ''Beyond the Pleasure Principle'' that the book not only "displayed a boldness of speculation that was unique in all his writings" but was "further noteworthy in being the only one of Freud's which has received little acceptance on the part of his followers".<ref>Jones, ''Life'', p. 505.</ref>
Otto Fenichel in his compendious survey of the first Freudian half-century concluded that "the facts on which Freud based his concept of a death instinct in no way necessitate the assumption [...] of a genuine self-destructive instinct".<ref>Otto Fenichel, ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'' (London, 1946), p. 60.</ref> [[Heinz Hartmann]] set the tone for [[ego psychology]] when he "chose to [...] do without 'Freud's other, mainly biologically oriented set of hypotheses of the "life" and "death instincts"'".<ref>Quoted in Gay, ''Freud'', pp. 402-3n.</ref> In the [[object relations theory]], among the independent group 'the most common repudiation was the loathsome notion of the death instinct'.<ref>Richard Appignanesi, ed., ''Introducing Melanie Klein'' (Cambridge, 2006), p. 157.</ref> Indeed, "for most analysts Freud's idea of a primitive urge towards death, of a primary masochism, was [...] bedevilled by problems".<ref>Gay, ''Freud'', p. 402.</ref>
Nevertheless, the concept has been defended, extended, and carried forward by some analysts, generally those tangential to the psychoanalytic mainstream; while among the more orthodox, arguably of "those who, in contrast to most other analysts, take Freud's doctrine of the death drive seriously, K. R. Eissler has been the most persuasive—or least unpersuasive".<ref>Gay, p. 768.</ref>
[[Melanie Klein]] and her immediate followers considered that "the infant is exposed from birth to the anxiety stirred up by the inborn polarity of instincts—the immediate conflict between the life instinct and the death instinct";<ref name=Segal>[[Hanna Segal]], ''Introduction to the work of Melanie Klein'' (London, 1964), p. 12.</ref> and Kleinians indeed built much of their theory of early childhood around the outward deflection of the latter. "This deflection of the death instinct, described by Freud, in Melanie Klein's view consists partly of a projection, partly of the conversion of the death instinct into aggression".<ref name=Segal />
French psychoanalyst [[Jacques Lacan]], for his part, castigated the "refusal to accept this culminating point of Freud's doctrine [...] by those who conduct their analysis on the basis of a conception of the ''ego'' [...] that death instinct whose enigma Freud propounded for us at the height of his experience".<ref>Lacan, ''Ecrits'', p. 101.</ref> Characteristically, he stressed the linguistic aspects of the death drive: "the symbol is substituted for death in order to take possession of the first swelling of life [...]. There is therefore no further need to have recourse to the outworn notion of primordial masochism in order to understand the reason for the repetitive games in [...] his ''Fort!'' and in his ''Da!''."<ref>Lacan, ''Ecrits'' pp. 124 and 103.</ref>
[[Eric Berne]] too would proudly proclaim that he, "besides having repeated and confirmed the conventional observations of Freud, also believes right down the line with him concerning the death instinct, and the pervasiveness of the [[repetition compulsion]]".<ref>Eric Berne, ''What Do You say After You Say Hello?'' (London, 1975) pp. 399-400.</ref>
For the twenty-first century, "the death drive today [...] remains a highly controversial theory for many psychoanalysts [...] [almost] as many opinions as there are psychoanalysts".<ref>Jean-Michel Quinodoz, ''Reading Freud'' (London, 2005), p. 193.</ref>
Freud's conceptual opposition of death and eros drives in the human psyche was applied by Walter A. Davis in ''Deracination: Historicity, Hiroshima, and the Tragic Imperative''<ref name=Adams01>{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Walter A.|title=Deracination; Historicity, Hiroshima, and the Tragic Imperative|date=2001|publisher=State University of New York Press|location=Albany|isbn=978-0-79144834-2}}</ref> and ''Death's Dream Kingdom: The American Psyche since 9/11.''<ref name=Adam02>{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Walter A.|title=Death's Dream Kingdom|date=2006|publisher=Pluto Press|location=London|isbn=978-0-74532468-5}}</ref> Davis described social reactions to both Hiroshima and 9/11 from the Freudian viewpoint of the death force. Unless they consciously take responsibility for the damage of those reactions, Davis claims that Americans will repeat them.

{{Use Irish English|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Philip Cairns | image = Philip Cairns.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Philip Cairns | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1973|9|1}} | birth_place = | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|1986|10|23|1973|9|1}} | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = {{Missing for|1986|10|23}} }}
'''Philip Cairns''' (born 1 September 1973) disappeared on the afternoon of 23 October 1986 while walking back to school in south [[Dublin]], Ireland. The 13-year-old schoolboy left his home in [[Ballyroan, Dublin|Ballyroan]] to return to school, but has not been seen since. A large-scale investigation was carried out but no trace of the boy has ever been found.<ref name="Ireland's disappeared people">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/irelands-disappeared-people-1248524.html|title=Ireland's disappeared people|date=16 December 2007|accessdate=4 June 2009|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref><ref name="'The next victim has every chance of being your mother ... or even you'The team handling the Garda's 'cold case' inquiries faces huge obstacles, writes Jim Cusack">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/the-next-victim-has-every-chance-of-being-your-mom--or-even-youthe-team-handling----the-gardas-cold-case-inquiries-faces-huge-obstacles-writes-------jim-cusack-1210772.html|title='The next victim has every chance of being your mom ... or even you'The team handling the Garda's 'cold case' inquiries faces huge obstacles, writes Jim Cusack|date=4 November 2007|accessdate=4 June 2009|work=[[Irish Independent]]}}</ref> His disappearance is now treated as a high-profile child murder case, the only similar incident in Ireland being the murder of [[Robert Holohan]] in January 2005.<ref name="Profile of a killer: What clues reveal">{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2005/01/16/story1606.asp |title=Profile of a killer: What clues reveal |date=16 January 2005 |accessdate=4 June 2009 |publisher=''[[The Sunday Business Post]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060117154703/http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2005/01/16/story1606.asp |archivedate=17 January 2006 |df= }}</ref> It is one of the most high-profile disappearances in recent Irish history.<ref name="Search for Philip Cairns to continue for third day"/>
Philip's family have issued numerous appeals for information. A reconstruction took place in 2007 and was later televised on [[RTÉ One]], while a reward of €10,000 has also been offered. The book, ''[[When Heaven Waits]]'', published in 2007, featured an interview with Philip's mother. Nobody has ever been arrested.<ref name="Search for Philip Cairns to continue for third day"/> The case remains open.
== Disappearance == {{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote="The very sad fact is that life went on after we lost Philip. I can remember we all went out and helped with the search, it was the neighbourly thing to do. But after a while you had to just get on with things. Young people, I think, are more resilient about things like that, they are able to forget more easily and put things behind them." |source= <small>Brendan Vaughn, former principal of Philip's school, [[Coláiste Éanna]] in [[Rathfarnham]].<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> </small> }} Philip Cairns disappeared while returning to school in [[Rathfarnham]].<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-23)"/><ref name="Land searched in Cairns disappearance"/> He had departed [[Coláiste Éanna]] secondary school at 12:45 to go home for lunch.<ref name="Gardaí begin new dig for missing boy"/><ref name="Search for missing schoolboy extended"/><ref name="Gardai to search woods for body in 22-year-old case"/> He left his home at 13:30 to return to Coláiste Éanna.<ref name="Gardaí begin new dig for missing boy"/><ref name="Search for missing schoolboy extended"/><ref name="Gardai to search woods for body in 22-year-old case"/> There have been no confirmed sightings of the boy since.<ref name="Gardaí begin new dig for missing boy"/> His family believe he was abducted by someone who knew him personally.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/>
Speculation at his school the day after his disappearance had Philip being kidnapped by a "bad man" who had offered him sweets then lured him into a van.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/>
== Investigation == Several hundred [[Garda Síochána]] officers and divers took part in a large-scale search of forests, lakes, mountains and rivers.<ref name="Gardaí begin new dig for missing boy"/> Psychics and clairvoyants were called in to assist.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> Posters were distributed by milk companies.<ref name="Area excavated in Philip Cairns probe"/> Cairns' classmates were interviewed by Gardaí at the school during their mid-term holiday break the following week.<ref name="Area excavated in Philip Cairns probe"/>
Six days after his disappearance, Philip's school bag was located by two girls in an alley close to his house.<ref name="Gardaí begin new dig for missing boy"/><ref name="Search for missing schoolboy extended"/><ref name="Family continue search 21 years on"/> The lane had already been searched, and the bag was not there at that time.<ref name="Search for Philip Cairns to continue for third day"/> The school bag was thought to hold vital clues, but nothing is known of how it came to be in the lane.<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-23)"/> It is thought the bag had been left there a short time previously.<ref name="Fresh appeal in Cairns disappearance case"/> It was examined forensically but no clues were located. Philip's implements, including pens, pencils, copybook, maths textbook, school journal and his pencil case were within.<ref name="Land searched in Cairns disappearance"/><ref name="Fresh appeal in Cairns disappearance case"/> Some of Philip's books were missing, including a geography book and two religion books.<ref name="Search for Philip Cairns to continue for third day"/><ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/><ref name="Search for missing schoolboy extended"/><ref name="Gardai to search woods for body in 22-year-old case"/><ref name="Family continue search 21 years on"/><ref name="Fresh appeal in Cairns disappearance case"/> A forensic examination produced no clues as to Philip's whereabouts.<ref name="Search for missing schoolboy extended"/> Gardaí have sealed the bag and it is now locked in a safe.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/><ref name="Schoolbag may hold DNA clue to disappearance 20 years ago">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/schoolbag-may-hold-dna-clue-to-disappearance-20-years-ago-74686.html|title=Schoolbag may hold DNA clue to disappearance 20 years ago|date=23 May 2006|accessdate=4 June 2009|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
Over 400 sightings were reported in the aftermath of the boy's disappearance.<ref name="Gardaí begin new dig for missing boy"/><ref name="Area excavated in Philip Cairns probe">{{cite web|url=http://www.examiner.ie/breakingnews/ireland/eyausngbqlcw/|title=Area excavated in Philip Cairns probe|date=6 May 2009|accessdate=4 June 2009|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''}}</ref> In one, Philip was reportedly seen in [[Manchester]] in the United Kingdom after his disappearance.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> Each sighting was seriously investigated, but none led to Philip.
Philip's parents appeared regularly on the news and clutched what has now become a well-recognised picture of a smiling Philip in his [[Confirmation]] clothes of a blue jacket and a red rosette.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> This photo has been deemed a precursor to that of British infant [[Disappearance of Madeleine McCann|Madeleine McCann]], who disappeared in [[Portugal]] 21 years later.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> However, the family, unlike the McCanns, have been relatively private about their loss, speaking to the media on only a few occasions in the past 25 years.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> It has been reported that this is due to several inaccurate reports of the incident of which they have disapproved.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> Gardaí have, however, praised the media as a proven method for encouraging people to come forward with further information on the case each time an appeal is broadcast.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> Residents' organisation ACRA also launched an intense campaign to attempt to find Philip.<ref name="Family continue search 21 years on">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/family-continue-search-21-years-on-1208463.html|title=Family continue search 21 years on|date=23 October 2006|accessdate=4 June 2009|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
Several theories have been reported by the media, most of which have been discounted by investigators. These have ranged from death by accident to Philip having been taken by extremists such as [[Pedophilia|paedophile]]s and [[Satanism|Satanist]]s.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> One theory had a woman tell gardaí that her partner, an alleged paedophile, had killed Philip after abducting him.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> This was later declared a false allegation.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/>
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote=“I hoped every day for months. I left the light on in the hall downstairs and in the bed at night. I used to listen to see if he would come in the door. You would be hoping the phone would ring and that would be him." |source= <small>Alice Cairns, speaking in the book ''When Heaven Waits''.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> </small> }} Detectives based at [[Rathfarnham Garda Station]] have been reinvestigating the disappearance of Philip Cairns for several years.<ref name="Land searched in Cairns disappearance"/> Several searches of land have been carried out in the years since the disappearance, often without the media being informed.<ref name="Land searched in Cairns disappearance"/>
In October 2006, the Cairns family issued an appeal for information on the twentieth anniversary of the disappearance.<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-23)">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1023/cairnsp.html|title=Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns|date=23 October 2006|accessdate=4 June 2009|publisher=[[Radio Telefís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-22)"/> They said they had not given up all hope of finding him alive.<ref name="Search for Philip Cairns to continue for third day">{{cite ===2016 investigation=== In May 2016 a woman contacted Gardaí to tell them that she suspected former DJ and convicted paedophile [[Eamonn Cooke]] of having killed Philip Cairns.<ref name=rte-gardai-believe-paedophile-dj-may-have-killed-philip-cairns>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2016/0610/794730-philip-cairns-information/|title=Gardaí believe paedophile may have killed missing schoolboy Philip Cairns|publisher=[[RTÉ News]]|date=10 Jun 2016|accessdate=11 Jun 2016}}</ref><ref name=ii-gardai-believe-paedophile-dj-may-have-killed-philip-cairns>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/gardai-believe-paedophile-dj-eamon-captain-cooke-may-have-killed-schoolboy-philip-cairns-34790504.html|title=Gardai believe paedophile DJ Eamon 'Captain' Cooke may have killed schoolboy Philip Cairns|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=10 Jun 2016|accessdate=11 Jun 2016|first=Cathal|last=McMahon}}</ref> Gardaí questioned Cooke and he was reported to have confirmed some details, but not to have revealed the location of Philip's body.<ref name=rte-gardai-believe-paedophile-dj-may-have-killed-philip-cairns/><ref name=ii-gardai-believe-paedophile-dj-may-have-killed-philip-cairns/> He died in June 2016.<ref name=ii-gardai-believe-paedophile-dj-may-have-killed-philip-cairns/>
In August 2016 it was announced that DNA samples taken from Philips' schoolbag did not match Cooke, but he had not been ruled out as a suspect.<ref name=rte-no-forensics-linking-cook-to-philip-cairns>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2016/0804/806905-cairns-disappearance-cooke/|title=No forensics linking Cooke to Philip Cairns|publisher=[[RTE News]]|date=4 August 2016|accessdate=4 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=ii-back-to-square-one>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/crime/back-to-square-one-garda-find-no-forensics-linking-eamon-cooke-to-missing-philip-cairns-34938600.html|title='Back to square one' - Gardaí find no forensics linking Eamon Cooke to missing Philip Cairns|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=4 August 2016|accessdate=4 August 2016}}</ref> Gardaí also sought to identify two people who may have left Philips' schoolbag in the laneway.<ref name=rte-no-forensics-linking-cook-to-philip-cairns/><ref name=ii-back-to-square-one/>
== Family == Philip's mother is Alice Cairns and his father was Philip Cairns, Snr.<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-22)"/> Alice is a grandmother now and lights a candle each evening in memory of her missing son.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/i-hoped-every-day-for-months-philip-cairns-1280067.html|title='I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns|date=3 February 2008|accessdate=4 June 2009|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> Philip has four sisters, Mary, Sandra, Helen and Suzanne.<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-22)"/> Sandra and Suzanne are active in organisations promoting missing children.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> He has one younger brother, Eoin, who was 11 years of age when Philip disappeared.<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-22)"/> Eoin has spoken of his memories of Philip which include childhood games of soccer, fishing and [[hurling]].<ref name="Fresh appeal from family of Philip Cairns (2006-10-22)"/>
His father, Phil, died on 6 July 2014 at [[Tallaght Hospital]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/father-of-missing-philip-cairns-passes-away-30412179.html|title=Father of missing Philip Cairns passes away|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=7 July 2014}}</ref>
==Impact== The disappearance of Philip Cairns affected the entire country.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/> The case was particularly unusual because it happened in the early afternoon and prompted parents to fear for the safety of their children, even in broad daylight.<ref name="'I hoped every day, for months': Philip Cairns"/>

'''Dmitriy Yurievich Shemyaka''' (Дмитрий Юрьевич Шемяка in [[Russian language|Russian]]) (died 1453) was the second son of [[Yury of Zvenigorod]] by Anastasia of [[Smolensk]] and grandson of [[Dmitri Donskoi]]. His hereditary patrimony was the rich Northern town [[Galich-Mersky]]. Shemyaka (1445, 1446–1447) was twice Grand Prince of [[Moscow]].
The causes of the [[Muscovite Civil War]] waged in the second quarter of the 15th century are still disputed. No small part, however, was played by [[Dmitri Donskoi]]'s will, which ran contrary to Rurikid dynastic custom whereby the throne would pass from an elder brother to a younger one ([[agnatic seniority]]), rather than from father to son ([[primogeniture]]). The testament provided for the accession of his son, Vasily I, which was still in keeping with the tradition of lateral succession since Vasily was the eldest of his generation.
In the event of Vasily having no surviving son at his death, his brother, Dmitry's second son, Yury of [[Zvenigorod]], was to succeed as grand prince in Moscow. Upon [[Vasily I]]'s death, however, Yury refused to come to Moscow and swear allegiance to his nephew, [[Vasily II]], and claimed the throne himself in accordance with his right under the long-held custom of lateral inheritance. (He further claimed it was provided for in Dmitry's testament – but this ignored the provision that voided Yury's succession in the event of Vasily I producing a son). Yury's son, Dmitry Shemyaka, actively participated in all of his father's incursions against Moscow, culminating in Yury's capture of Moscow and accession as grand prince in 1433. Yury of Zvenigorod died in Moscow in 1434.
[[Image:Meeting of Dmitry Shemyaka with Vasily II..jpg|thumb|250px|''Meeting of Shemyaka with Vasily II after the Latter's Blinding''.]]
After Yury's death, Shemyaka continued to press his branch's claim to the grand princely throne, and was seldom at peace with Vasily II. Initially, Dmitry and his younger brother [[Dmitry Krasnyi]] concluded an alliance with Vasily against their elder brother [[Vasily Kosoy]], who had proclaimed himself grand prince. They succeeded in driving Kosoy from [[Moscow]] and were rewarded with the towns of [[Uglich]] and [[Rzhev]]. The following year Shemyaka came to [[Moscow]] in order to invite [[Vasily II]] to his impending wedding with a princess of [[Yaroslavl]], but was accused of siding with Kosoy and taken prisoner. Released several months later, he was sent by Vasily II to defend [[Belyov]] against a small army of the [[Kazan Khanate|Kazan Khan]] [[Olug Moxammat]] but was defeated. Thereupon he refused to support Vasily in his hostilities against the khan, and only the mediation of a [[Troitse-Sergiyeva Lavra|Trinity hegumen]] could forestall a new civil war between the cousins.
The two men maintained an uneasy peace for much of the next decade until 1445, when Vasily II was taken prisoner by Olug Moxammat after the Muscovite forces were surprised by the Tatar prince outside Suzdal, Shemyaka seized [[Moscow]], had the recently released Vasily blinded and proclaimed himself the Grand Prince of Vladimir. He could claim this by right of lateral inheritance since his father had sat on the throne. (A prince was excluded from the succession (izgoi) if his father had not sat on the throne before him.) Shemyaka's lack of support among the Muscovite boyars forced him, however, to leave the city for [[Lake Chukhloma]], but he continued to press his claim to the grand princely throne.
Despite several peace treaties, Shemyaka continued to plot against his cousin. He suffered a series of defeats in 1450 and 1452 which forced him to seek refuge in [[Republic of Novgorod|Novgorod]]. There, on July 17, 1453, he was poisoned while eating a dinner of chicken in the Gorodishche, the princely compound south of the Market side of the city,<ref>Valentin Yanin, "Posmertnaia Sudba Dmitriia Shemiaki," in ''Srednevekovyi Novgorod'' (Moscow: Nauka, 2004), 342.</ref> his cook having been bribed by Muscovite agents. Delighted at the news, Vasily II ennobled a herald who had first brought him the message of Shemyaka's death. Nikolai Karamzin famously wrote in his history that the grand prince showed "indecent joy" at the news of his rival's untimely demise.
According to chronicle sources, Shemyaka was buried in the Church of St. George in the [[Yuriev Monastery]] south of Novgorod, <ref>Yanin, "Posmertnaia Sudba Dmitriia Shemiaki," 342.</ref> however, twentieth-century archaeological excavations of the necropolis of the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod|Cathedral of Holy Wisdom]] in the [[Novgorod Kremlin]] suggest that the prince was actually buried there and his grave has been misidentified since at least 1616 as that of Prince Fedor Yaroslavich (died 1233).<ref>Yanin, ''Nekropol' Novgorodskogo Sofiiskogo sobora: tserkovnaia traditsiia i istoricheskaia kritika'' (Moscow: Nauka, 1988), 89-113; Idem, "Posmertnaia Sudba Dmitriia Shemiaki", 337-346.</ref>
In the aftermath of Shemyaka's murder, his wife and son fled [[Novgorod]] to the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]], where they were given [[Rylsk, Russia|Rylsk]] and [[Novgorod-Seversky]] in appanage.
Shemyaka's male line died out by 1561, but there are many living descendants from his daughter's marriage to Prince [[Czartoryski|Alexander Chertoryzhsky]].
Shemyaka's name survives in the [[Russian language|Russian]] expression "Shemyakin sud" ("Shemyaka's Justice", "Shemyaka's Judgement"), which means hasty and unfair judgement. It comes from the 17th century literary work ''The Tale of Shemyaka's Judgement'' (see its translation here<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=tV-27KrCerYC&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183&dq=%22shemyaka+judg%22&source=bl&ots=QKVxCHn4Tx&sig=b26Km3iVYpgoybxpRtrCwelsfv4&hl=en&ei=eruTTL2nKI7CsAPSyojBCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&sqi=2&ved=0CBcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false "The Judgment of Shemyaka"]</ref>). However modern researchers question the identification of Dmitry Shemyaka with Judge Shemyaka in the tale. <!-- one may pick refs for this claim (and expand this bit) from the well-referenced page in Russian Wikipedia -->

[[File:Caesius facial composite.jpg|thumb|Bilateral features in the face and body, such as left and right eyes, ears, lips, wrists and thighs, often show some extent of fluctuating asymmetry. Some individuals show greater asymmetry than others. ]] As a form of biological asymmetry, '''fluctuating asymmetry''' ('''FA'''), along with anti-symmetry and direction asymmetry, refers to small, random deviations away from perfect [[Symmetry in biology|bilateral symmetry]].<nowiki/><ref name="Valen1962">{{cite journal|last=Valen|first=Leigh Van|title=A Study of Fluctuating Asymmetry|journal=Evolution|date=June 1962|volume=16|issue=2|pages=125–142|jstor=2406192|doi=10.2307/2406192}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Fluctuating Asymmetry|last=Tomkins|first=J. L.|last2=Kotiaho|first2=J. S.|publisher=Macmillan Publishers Ltd.|year=2001|isbn=|location=London|pages=1–5}}</ref> This deviation from perfection is thought to reflect the genetic and environmental pressures experienced throughout development, with greater pressures resulting in higher levels of asymmetry.<ref name="Valen1962" /> Examples of FA in the human body include unequal sizes (asymmetry) of bilateral features in the face and body, such as left and right eyes, ears, wrists, [[breast]]s, [[testicle]]s, and thighs.
Research has exposed multiple factors that are associated with FA. As measuring FA can indicate developmental stability, it can also suggest the genetic fitness of an individual. This can further have an effect on mate attraction and sexual selection, as less asymmetry reflects greater developmental stability and subsequent fitness.<ref name=":1" /> Human [[Health|physical health]] is also associated with FA. For example, young men with greater FA report more medical conditions than those with lower levels of FA.<ref name="Fluctuating asymmetry and physical health among young adults" /> Multiple other factors can be linked to FA, such as intelligence<ref name=":1" /> and personality traits.<ref name=":2" />
== Measurement == Fluctuating asymmetry (FA) can be measured by the equation: Mean FA = mean absolute value of left sides - mean absolute value of right sides.
The closer the mean value is to zero, the lower the levels of FA, indicating more symmetrical features. By taking many measurements of multiple traits per individual, this increases the accuracy in determining that individual's developmental stability. However, these traits must be chosen carefully, as different traits are affected by different selection pressures.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Patrice|first=D.|last2=Hingle|first2=A.|last3=Fowler|first3=K.|last4=Pomiankowski|first4=A.|date=1999|title=Measurement bias and fluctuating asymmetry estimates.|url=|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=57|issue=1|pages=251–253|doi=10.1006/anbe.1998.0977|pmid=}}</ref>
This equation can further be used to study the distribution of asymmetries at population levels, to distinguish between traits that show FA, directional asymmetry, and anti-symmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Swaddle|first=J. P.|date=2003|title=Fluctuating asymmetry, animal behaviour, and evolution.|url=|journal=Advances in the study of behaviour.|doi=|pmid=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Palmer|first=R.|last2=Strobeck|first2=C.|date=1992|title=Fluctuating asymmetry as a measure of developmental stability: Implications of non-normal distributions and power of statistical tests.|url=|journal=Acta Zoologica Fennica|pages=57–72|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> The distribution of FA around a mean point of zero suggests that FA is not an adaptive trait, where symmetry is ideal. Directional asymmetry of traits can be distinguished by showing significantly biased measurements towards traits being larger on either the left or right sides, for example, human [[testicle]]s (where the right is more commonly larger), or handedness (85% are right handed, 15% are left handed). Anti-symmetry can be distinguished by the bimodal distributions, due to some adaptive functions.
== Causes == Fluctuating asymmetry (FA) is often considered to be the product of [[Developmental biology|developmental]] stress and instability, caused by both genetic and environmental stressors. The notion that FA is a result of genetic and environmental factors is supported by [[C. H. Waddington|Waddington's]] notion of [[Canalisation (genetics)|canalisation]], which implies that FA is a measure of the [[genome|genome's]] ability to successfully buffer development to achieve a normal [[phenotype]] under imperfect environmental conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=WADDINGTON|first=C. H.|title=Canalization of Development and the Inheritance of Acquired Characters|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/150563a0|journal=Nature|volume=150|issue=3811|pages=563–565|doi=10.1038/150563a0}}</ref> Various factors causing developmental instability and FA include [[infection]]s, [[mutation]]s, and [[toxin]]s.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The evolutionary biology of human female sexuality|last=Thornhill, Gangestad|first=Randy, Steven W.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=0195340981|location=Oxford, England|pages=162–168}}</ref>
=== Genetic factors === Research on [[twin]]s suggests that there are genetic influences on FA,<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Wendy|last2=Segal|first2=Nancy L.|last3=Bouchard Jr.|first3=Thomas J.|date=2008-05-01|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and general intelligence: No genetic or phenotypic association|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289607000967|journal=Intelligence|volume=36|issue=3|pages=279–288|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2007.07.001}}</ref> and increased levels of mutations and perturbations is also linked to greater asymmetry.<ref name=":1" />
FA may also result from a lack of genetic immunity to diseases, as those with higher FA show less effective immune responses.<ref name=":3" /> This is further supported by evidence showing an association between FA and the number of respiratory infections experienced by an individual, such that those with higher levels of FA experience more infections.<ref name=":1" /> Increased prevalence of parasites and diseases in an organism is also seen more in individuals with greater levels of FA.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Fink|first=Bernhard|last2=Neave|first2=Nick|last3=Manning|first3=John T.|last4=Grammer|first4=Karl|date=2006-08-01|title=Facial symmetry and judgements of attractiveness, health and personality|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886906000973|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=41|issue=3|pages=491–499|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2006.01.017}}</ref> However, the research in this field is predominantly correlational, so caution must be taken when inferring causation. For example, rather than a lack of immunity causing FA, FA may weaken the immune responses of an organism, or there may be another factor involved.
There is some speculation that [[inbreeding]] contributes towards FA. One study on young Turkish males demonstrated that, although inbred individuals show more asymmetry in observed bilateral traits, the differences were not significant.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Özener|first=Bariş|date=2010-07-01|title=Effect of inbreeding depression on growth and fluctuating asymmetry in Turkish young males|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajhb.21046/abstract|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|language=en|volume=22|issue=4|pages=557–562|doi=10.1002/ajhb.21046|issn=1520-6300}}</ref> Furthermore, ant colonies created by an inbreeding queen do not show significantly higher FA than those produced by a non-inbreeding queen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Keller|first=Laurent|last2=Passera|first2=Luc|date=1993-09-01|title=Incest avoidance, fluctuating asymmetry, and the consequences of inbreeding in Iridomyrmex humilis, an ant with multiple queen colonies|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00216600|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|language=en|volume=33|issue=3|pages=191–199|doi=10.1007/BF00216600|issn=0340-5443}}</ref>
=== Environmental factors === Multiple sources provide information on environmental factors that are correlated with FA. A meta-analysis of related studies suggests that FA is an appropriate marker of environmental stress during development.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Beasley|first=De Anna E.|last2=Bonisoli-Alquati|first2=Andrea|last3=Mousseau|first3=Timothy A.|date=2013-07-01|title=The use of fluctuating asymmetry as a measure of environmentally induced developmental instability: A meta-analysis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1470160X13000988|journal=Ecological Indicators|volume=30|pages=218–226|doi=10.1016/j.ecolind.2013.02.024}}</ref>
Some evidence suggests that [[poverty]] and [[Malnutrition|lack of food]] during development may contribute to greater levels of FA.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ozener|first=Bariş|date=2011-12-01|title=Does urban poverty increase body fluctuating asymmetry?|journal=Collegium Antropologicum|volume=35|issue=4|pages=1001–1005|issn=0350-6134|pmid=22397230}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mallard|first=Samantha T.|last2=Barnard|first2=C. J.|date=2004-02-01|title=Food stress, fluctuating asymmetry and reproductive performance in the gryllid crickets Gryllus bimaculatus and Gryllodes sigillatus|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/156853904322890825|journal=Behaviour|volume=141|issue=2|pages=219–232|doi=10.1163/156853904322890825|issn=1568-539X}}</ref> [[Infection|Infectious diseases]] can also lead to FA, as studies have repeatedly shown that those with higher FA report more infections.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Møller|first=Anders Pape|date=2006-03-01|title=A review of developmental instability, parasitism and disease: Infection, genetics and evolution|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S156713480500064X|journal=Infection, Genetics and Evolution|volume=6|issue=2|pages=133–140|doi=10.1016/j.meegid.2005.03.005}}</ref> Alternatively, this association between levels of FA and infections may be due to a lack of immunity to diseases, as mentioned earlier (see 'Genetic factors'). Fluctuating asymmetry in human males is also seen to positively correlate with levels of [[oxidative stress]]. This process occurs when an organism creates excess reactive oxygen species (ROS) compared to ROS-neutralising antioxidants.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gangestad|first=Steven W.|last2=Merriman|first2=Leslie A.|last3=Emery Thompson|first3=Melissa|date=2010-12-01|title=Men’s oxidative stress, fluctuating asymmetry and physical attractiveness|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347210003416|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=80|issue=6|pages=1005–1013|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2010.09.003}}</ref> Oxidative stress may mediate the association seen between high FA and infection amounts during development.<ref name=":1" />
Toxins and poisons are considered to increase FA. [[Morning sickness|Pregnancy sickness]] is argued to be an [[adaptation]] for avoiding toxins during [[Prenatal development|foetal development]]. Research has reported that when a mother has no sickness or a sickness that extends beyond week 12 of gestation, the offspring shows higher FA (as demonstrated by measuring thigh circumferences). This suggests that when a mother fails to expel environmental toxins, this creates stress and developmental instability for the foetus, later leading to increased asymmetry in that individual.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Singh|first=Devendra|last2=Rosen|first2=Valerie C.|title=Effects of maternal body morphology, morning sickness, gestational diabetes and hypertension on fluctuating asymmetry in young women|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1090513801000824|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|volume=22|issue=6|pages=373–384|doi=10.1016/s1090-5138(01)00082-4}}</ref> Greater exposure to [[pollution]] may also be a fundamental cause of FA. Research on skull characteristics of [[Grey seal|Baltic grey seals]] (''Halichoerus grypus'') demonstrated that those born after 1960 (marking an increase in environmental pollution) had increased levels of asymmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zakharov|first=Vladmir M.|last2=Yablokov|first2=Alexay V.|date=1990-01-01|title=Skull Asymmetry in the Baltic Grey Seal: Effects of Environmental Pollution|journal=Ambio|volume=19|issue=5|pages=266–269|jstor=4313708}}</ref> Also, [[Greater white-toothed shrew|shrews]] (''Crocidura russula)'' from more polluted areas show higher levels of asymmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sánchez-Chardi|first=Alejandro|last2=García-Pando|first2=Marián|last3=López-Fuster|first3=María José|date=2013-10-01|title=Chronic exposure to environmental stressors induces fluctuating asymmetry in shrews inhabiting protected Mediterranean sites|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0045653513008023|journal=Chemosphere|volume=93|issue=6|pages=916–923|doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2013.05.056|pmid=23800592}}</ref> Radioactive contamination may also increase FA levels, as [[Yellow-necked mouse|mice]] (''Apodemus flavicollis'') living closer to the failed [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl reactor]] show greater asymmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oleksyk|first=Taras K|last2=Novak|first2=James M|last3=Purdue|first3=James R|last4=Gashchak|first4=Sergiy P|last5=Smith|first5=Michael H|date=2004-01-01|title=High levels of fluctuating asymmetry in populations of Apodemus flavicollis from the most contaminated areas in Chornobyl|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0265931X03002224|journal=Journal of Environmental Radioactivity|volume=73|issue=1|pages=1–20|doi=10.1016/j.jenvrad.2003.07.001}}</ref>
== Developmental stability == Developmental stability is achieved when an organism is able to withstand genetic and environmental stress, to display the bilaterally symmetrical traits determined by its developmentally programmed phenotype.<ref name="Valen1962" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Markow|first=Therese Ann|date=1995-01-01|title=Evolutionary Ecology and Developmental Instability|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev.en.40.010195.000541|journal=Annual Review of Entomology|volume=40|issue=1|pages=105–120|doi=10.1146/annurev.en.40.010195.000541|pmid=<!--none-->}}</ref> To measure an individual's developmental stability, the FA measurements of 10 traits are added together, including ear width, elbows, ankles, wrists, feet, length of ears and fingers. This is achieved by: (L - R)trait 1 + (L - R)trait 2 + ......(L - R)trait 10. This provides a good overall measure of body FA, as every individual has some features that are not perfectly symmetrical.
Common environmental pressures leading to lower developmental stability include exposure to toxins, poison and infectious diseases, low food quality and malnutrition. Genetic pressures include spontaneous new mutations, and "bad genes" (genes that once had adaptive functions, but are being removed through evolutionary selection). A large fluctuating asymmetry (FA) and a low developmental stability suggests that an organism is unable to develop according to the ideal state of bilateral symmetry. The energy required for bilateral symmetry development is extremely high, making perfect bilateral symmetry rare. Energy is invested into survival in spite of the genetic and environmental pressures, before making bilaterally symmetrical traits. Research has also revealed links between FA and depression, genetic or environmental stress and measures of mate quality for sexual selection.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Graham | first1 = J. H. | year = 1992 | title = Genomic coadaption and development stability in hybrid zones | url = | journal = Acta Zool. Fenn. | volume = 191 | issue = | pages = 121–132 }}</ref><ref>Graham, J. H., D. C. Freeman and J. M. Emlen. 1993. Developmental stability: A sensitive indicator of populations under stress, pp. 1366158. /)I W. G. Landis, J. S. Hughes and M. A. Lewis (Eds.), Environmental Toxicology and Risk Assessment. American Society for Testing and Materials, Philadelphia, PA.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tomkins | first1 = J. L. | last2 = Simmons | first2 = L. W. | year = 1995 | title = Patterns of fluctuating asymmetry in earwig forceps: No evidence for reliable signalling | url = | journal = Proc. Roy. Soc. Lond. B | volume = 259 | issue = | pages = 89–96 | doi=10.1098/rspb.1995.0014}}</ref><ref>Moller, A. P. 1994. Sexual Selection and the Barn Swallow. Oxford University Press. Oxford.</ref>
==Health==
===Susceptibility to diseases===
Research has linked higher levels of fluctuating asymmetry (FA) to poorer outcomes in some domains of physical health in humans. For example, one study found that individuals with higher levels of FA report a higher number of medical conditions than those with lower levels of FA. However, they did not experience worse outcomes in areas such as systolic blood pressure or cholesterol levels.<ref name="Fluctuating asymmetry and physical health among young adults">{{cite journal|last1=Milne|first1=Barry J|last2=Belsky|first2=Jay|last3=Poulton|first3=Richie|last4=Thomson|first4=W. Murray|last5=Caspi|first5=Avshalom|last6=Kieser|first6=Jules|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and physical health among young adults|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=January 2003|volume=24|issue=1|pages=53–63|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(02)00120-4|url=http://0-www.sciencedirect.com.pugwash.lib.warwick.ac.uk/science/article/pii/S1090513802001204|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> Higher levels of FA have also been linked to higher body mass index (BMI) in women,<ref name="Fluctuating asymmetry and physical health among young adults" /> and lower BMI in men.<ref name="FA and body weight in men and women">{{cite journal|last1=Manning|first1=John T|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and body weight in men and women: Implications for sexual selection|journal=Ethology and Sociobiology|date=March 1995|volume=16|issue=2|pages=145–153|doi=10.1016/0162-3095(94)00074-H|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/016230959400074H/1-s2.0-016230959400074H-main.pdf?_tid=ba52cf68-d71f-11e5-b323-00000aacb360&acdnat=1455896877_3d1b740b1d5b2045cc573be64cf74840|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> Research has shown that both men and women with higher levels of FA, both facial and bodily, report a higher number of respiratory infections and a higher number of days ill, dimorphism, developmental stability, and susceptibility to disease in men and women|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=March 2006|volume=27|issue=2|pages=131–144|doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2005.06.001|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513805000528/1-s2.0-S1090513805000528-main.pdf?_tid=7c412804-d720-11e5-b024-00000aab0f01&acdnat=1455897203_42f352a89b6ef98317bd901d2dd73363|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> In men, higher levels of FA have been linked to lower levels of physical attractiveness and higher levels of oxidative stress, regardless of smoking or levels of toxin February 2016}}</ref> There is no gender difference in the susceptibility of diseases depending on body FA.<ref>"Gangsted2006">{{cite 2016}}</ref>
A large-scale review of the human and non-human literature by Møller found that higher levels of fluctuating asymmetry were linked to increased vulnerability to parasites, and also to lower levels of immunity to disease.<ref name="FA and parasitism">{{cite journal|last1=Møller|first1=Anders Pape|title=A review of developmental instability, parasitism and disease: Infection, genetics and evolution|journal=Infection, Genetics and Evolution|date=April 2006|volume=6|issue=2|pages=133–140|doi=10.1016/j.meegid.2005.03.005|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Anders_Moller3/publication/7499373_A_review_of_developmental_instability_parasitism_and_disease_Infection_genetics_and_evolution/links/00b7d52e4e4d8303df000000.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref> A large-scale longitudinal study in Britain found that facial FA was not associated with poorer health over the course of childhood, which was interpreted as suggesting smaller effects of FA in Western societies with generally low levels of FA <ref name="FA and childhood disease UK study">{{cite journal|last1=Pound|first1=Nicholas|last2=Lawson|first2=David W.|last3=Toma|first3=Arshed M.|last4=Richmond|first4=Stephen|last5=Zhurov|first5=Alexei I.|last6=Penton-Voak|first6=Ian S.|title=Facial fluctuating asymmetry is not associated with childhood attractiveness features and health in Western societies produced similar results, finding that symmetry was not related to health in either sex, but was related to attractiveness in males.<ref name="FA and health in Western societies">{{cite journal|last1=Weeden|first1=Jason|last2=Sabini|first2=John|title=Physical Attractiveness and Health in Western Societies: A
